content.description: This climbs the steep overhang above and to the left of the roof crack Fisticuffs.  Start on the jug of Fisticuffs. Climb the short finger crack to a horizontal break underneath the overhang. Load up the roof seam with gear and bust a move or two out to the huge horn at the lip. Wall on the left side (that cave wave is located on) is OFF unless you want to bail. Plug in some more gear here (threaded sling and #3 camalot) and pull the lip using the arete. A couple insecure slab moves lead the the top. You can set up a belay off a #1 and #2 camalot.
content.protection: Medium sized stoppers, tcu's, #1 #2 and #3 camalot OR every pad you can find.
content.location: Start at the jug on Fisticuffs.

content.description: Nestling is an overlooked gem.  Start in the cave/corridor on large rails.  Climb up for a couple of fun moves on large holds and pull around the right arete delicately to reach the lip and mantle.  Be sure not to blow it up high.  This is my favorite V1 at the Stable, a place that is stacked with quality climbs at the V1 grade.
content.protection: A pad or two and maybe a spotter.
content.location: Leaning up against the boulder that has the Cave Wave dyno and across from the Herr problems is a large boulder which has somewhat of a cave.  Nestling begins in the cave and exits right around the arete to gain the lip.

content.description: Climb the tall crack that starts wide, goes to a horizontal break, then narrows to a 3 or 4 inch crack which can be liebacked on the right side or jammed securely straight on.  This is one of the nicer easy cracks at the stables.
content.location: The tall crack right of the Herr Brother's problems.

content.description: Tall and proud, this line has a little bit of everything.  Start with easy enough moves utilizing the arete to gain a high crimp, then bust out the crux toward a flat lip.  Don't look down.
content.protection: A couple pads.  It's pretty high
content.location: Right side of the tree that splits the Herr problems

content.description: Herr Left's grade is entirely dependent on height.  If you're under 5'7" it's V3.  If you're over 5'11" it's V6.  V5 seems to be a good compromise
content.protection: A couple pads, it's pretty tall and wanders a bit.
content.location: Left side of the tree splitting the Herr problems

content.description: Trad climbers rejoice! Offwidths and chimneys do exist on the East Coast, they're just boulder problems. Climb the chimney on this one to a high and exposed topout above Herr Right.
content.protection: A few pads.  It's a long way down from the moves after the chimney
content.location: The obvious chimney between Herr Left and Herr Right. There's also a V3 variation that eliminates the chimney and used only the right rock, called Herr Lieback. It's rad too.

content.description:
Fisticuffs is unique to Governor Stables, and diabase rock in general, in that it is a parallel hand and fist jam crack, and on a horizontal roof to boot!  If you like these kind of challenges then you will not be disappointed. 

  This roof crack is down low in a sort of cave opposite of the tall and sweeping face which contains the V6 dyno problem Cave Wave.  Look down and underneath the roof to locate the crack.  It is easy to miss if you are not looking for it. 

  Burrow as far back as you can in to the beginning of the roof crack and start jamming.  After a couple of moves turn the lip to vertical territory.  Once standing on the vertical face, you may step off, of continue upwards on grungy but easy rock to a top out.  Taping may be prudent as the insides of the crack are quite gritty, but taping is not a deal breaker.  The crack is hand as well as fist sized with good, solid jams for hands and feet.
content.protection: One or two pads, no spotter.  The crack is no more than four or five feet off of the ground.  It is very safe and the jams are secure.
content.location: Fisticuffs is on the right side of the alcove that is downhill from the Herr Brothers Arete problems.  Looming over you will be a jutting roof that is led with traditional protection or toproped.  To the left of the little cave is the tall and sweeping Cave Wave face with a poor landing.  The problem Fisticuffs faces away from the Stables entrance, if that helps.

content.description: Terrifying to look at, but not all that bad.  The trick is to commit, because if you don't... well, just commit.  Start with your left foot in the seam and your right hand on the crimp in the  middle of the face.  Launch for the lip with both hands, then top it out.
content.protection: A few pads for sure, and a spotter doesn't hurt either.  As long as you commit to the move you'll miss all the intimidating protrusions, and the landing is a okay.
content.location: Just off the trail near C Sit, opposite the Creekside boulder.

content.description: Small area containing the ultra classic Herr Left and Herr Right, and a few other problems as well
